text: Solve this problem step by step.
End with 'DONE.' when you have a solution.
Question: A man lives on the 10th floor of an apartment building.
Every morning he takes the elevator down to the ground floor to go to work.
When he returns in the evening, he takes the elevator to the 7th floor and walks up the stairs for the remaining three floors to reach his apartment.
However, on rainy days, he takes the elevator all the way to the 10th floor.

Why does he only take the elevator to the 7th floor on non-rainy days? 

 Solution: 
<think>
Okay, so I'm trying to figure out why this man takes the elevator only to the 7th floor on non-rainy days.
Let's break down the problem step by step.
First, the man lives on the 10th floor.
Every morning, he takes the elevator down to the ground floor, which is the 1st floor.
That makes sense because he's going to work.
In the evening, when he returns, he takes the elevator up to the 7th floor and then walks up the stairs for the remaining three floors to get to his apartment on the 10th floor.
So, on normal days, he doesn't take the elevator all the way home; he stops at the 7th floor and walks.
But then, on rainy days, he takes the elevator all the way to the 10th floor.
So why the change? There must be something about the rain that makes him take the elevator further.
Maybe the stairs are slippery when it's raining, so he doesn't want to walk up three flights.
That seems plausible because walking on wet stairs can be dangerous and slippery.
Wait, but why doesn't he just take the elevator all the way every day? Maybe the elevator isn't running during the morning or evening, but that doesn't make sense because he does take it both ways.
Alternatively, maybe the elevator is faster or more convenient, but he's already taking it down in the morning.

So why not take it all the way home?

Another angle: maybe the building has a policy about taking the elevator after a certain time, but that's not mentioned.
Or perhaps the man wants to save time or effort, so on rainy days, he doesn't want to walk, but on dry days, he prefers walking the stairs for some reason.
But the main difference is the rain.
So, likely, on rainy days, the stairs are too slippery, making it unsafe to walk up three floors.
Therefore, he takes the elevator all the way to the 10th floor to avoid the slippery stairs.
Wait, but on non-rainy days, he takes the elevator only to the 7th floor.
Why not take it all the way? Maybe the elevator isn't available or it's too slow, so he prefers walking the stairs when it's not raining.
Or perhaps he likes the exercise of walking up the stairs.
Alternatively, maybe the elevator is out of order or he's trying to save on elevator costs.
But the problem specifically mentions rainy days, so the key factor is the rain.
On rainy days, he doesn't want to walk on wet stairs, so he takes the elevator all the way.
On non-rainy days, he's comfortable walking up the stairs, so he takes the elevator only to the 7th floor and walks the remaining three floors.

So, putting it all together, the reason he takes the elevator only to the 7th floor on non-rainy days is because on rainy days, the stairs are slippery, making it unsafe to walk, so he takes the elevator all the way.
On dry days, the stairs are safe, so he prefers walking the stairs instead of taking the elevator all the way, perhaps because it's quicker or he likes the exercise.
Alternatively, maybe the elevator is faster, but he's saving time by not taking it all the way on dry days.
Or maybe the building has a rule against taking the elevator after a certain floor, but that's not stated.
I think the main reason is the safety aspect due to the rain making the stairs slippery.
Therefore, on rainy days, he uses the elevator, and on dry days, he walks the stairs because they're safe.

</think>

The man takes the elevator only to the 7th floor on non-rainy days because when it's raining, the stairs become slippery, making it unsafe to walk up.
Therefore, on rainy days, he takes the elevator all the way to the 10th floor to avoid the slippery stairs.
On dry days, he prefers walking the remaining three floors as the stairs are safe and perhaps he finds it quicker or more convenient.
